Sec. 2-112. - Purpose. The purpose of this code of ethics is to: (1) Encourage high ethical standards in official conduct by city officials; (2) Establish guidelines for ethical standards of conduct for all such officials by setting forth those acts or actions that are incompatible with the interest of the city; (3) Require disclosure by such officials of private financial or other interest in matters affecting the city; and (4) Serve as a basis for disciplining those who refuse to abide by its terms. (Ord. of 7-30-2011, § 1) Sec. 2-113. - Scope. The provisions of this code of ethics shall be applicable to all elected or appointed city officials. Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, state law and the Charter of the city shall be controlling in the event of an actual conflict with the provisions of this code of ethics. This division shall be interpreted to supplement, and not replace, said provisions of state law and the Charter. (Ord. of 7-30-2011, § 1) Sec. 2-114. - Definitions. Solely for the purpose of this code of ethics: (1) City official or official , unless otherwise expressly defined does not include city employees but does mean the mayor, members of the city council, municipal court judges (including substitute judges), city manager, city clerk, city attorney, and all other persons holding positions designated by the city charter, as amended. The term "city official" also includes all individuals, including city employees, appointed by the mayor and/or city council as appropriate to city authorities, commissions, committees, boards, task forces, or other bodies which can or may vote or take formal action or make official recommendations to the mayor and/or city council. (2) Decision means any ordinance, resolution, contract, franchise, formal action, or other matter voted on by the city council or other city board or commission, as well as the discussions or deliberations of the council, board, or commission which can or may lead to a vote or formal action by that body. (3) Employee means any person who is a full-time or part-time employee of the city. (4) Immediate family means the spouse, mother, father, grandparent, brother, sister, son, or daughter of any city official related by blood, adoption or marriage. The relationship by marriage shall include in-laws. (5) Incidental interest means an interest in a person, entity or property which is not a substantial interest as defined herein and which has insignificant value. (6) Remote interest means an interest of a person or entity, including a city official, which would be affected in the same way as the general public. For example, the interest of an official in the property tax rate, general city fees, city utility charges, or a comprehensive zoning ordinance or similar matters is deemed remote to the extent that the official would be affected in common with the general public. (7) Substantial interest means an interest, either directly or through a member of the immediate family, in another person or entity, where: a. The interest is ownership of five percent or more of the voting stock, shares, or equity of the entity or ownership of $5,000.00 or more of the equity or market value of the entity; or b. The funds received by the person from the other person or entity during the previous 12 months either equal or exceed: (a) $5,000.00 in salary, bonuses, commissions, or professional fees, or $5,000.00 in payment for goods, products or services; or (b) ten percent of the recipient's gross income during that period, whichever is less; c. The person serves as a corporate officer or member of the board of directors or other governing board of a for-profit entity other than a corporate entity owned or created by the city council; or d. The person is a creditor, debtor, or guarantor of the other person or entity in an amount of $5,000.00 or more. (Ord. of 7-30-2011, § 1) Sec. 2-115. - Prohibitions. (a) No city official shall use such position to secure special privileges or exemptions for himself or herself or others, or to secure confidential information for any purpose other than official duties of behalf of the city. (b) No city official, in any matter before the council or other city body, relating to a person or entity in which the official has a substantial interest, shall fail to disclose for the record such interest prior to any discussion or vote or fail to recuse himself/herself from such discussion or vote as applicable. (c) No city official shall act as an agent or attorney for another in any matter before the city council or other city body. (d) No city official shall directly or indirectly receive, or agree to receive, any compensation, gift, reward, or gratuity in any matter or proceeding connected with, or related to, the duties of his office except as may be provided by law. (e) No city official shall enter into any contract with, or have any interest in, either directly or indirectly, the city except as authorized by state law. (1) This prohibition shall not be applicable to the professional activities of the city attorney in his or her work as an independent contractor and legal advisor on behalf of the city. (2) This prohibition shall not be applicable to an otherwise valid employment contract between the city and a city official who is not elected (such as, by way of example, a city manager, city administrator, or chief of police). (3) Any official who has a proprietary interest in an agency doing business with the city shall make that interest known in writing to the city council and the city clerk. (f) All public funds shall be used for the general welfare of the people and not for personal economic gain. (g) Public property shall be disposed of in accordance with state law. (h) No city official shall solicit or accept other employment to be performed, or compensation to be received, while still a city official if the employment or compensation could reasonably be expected to impair such official's judgment or performance of city duties. (i) If a city official accepts or is soliciting a promise of future employment from any person or entity who has a substantial interest in a person, entity, or property which would be affected by any decision upon which the official might reasonably be expected to act, investigate, advise, or make a recommendation, the official shall disclose the fact to the city council and shall recuse himself/herself and take no further action on matters regarding the potential future employer. (j) No city official shall use city facilities, personnel, equipment, or supplies for private purposes, except to the extent such are lawfully available to the public. (k) No city official shall grant or make available to any person any consideration, treatment, advantage, or favor beyond that which it is the general practice to grant or make available to the public at large. (l) A city official shall not directly or indirectly make use of, or permit others to make use of, official information not made available to the general public for the purpose of furthering a private interest. (m) A city official shall not use his or her position in any way to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, another person to provide any financial benefit to such official or persons within the official's immediate family, or those with whom the official has business or financial ties amounting to a substantial interest. (n) A city official shall not order any goods and services for the city without prior official authorization for such an expenditure. No city official shall attempt to obligate the city nor give the impression of obligating the city without proper prior authorization. (o) No city official shall draw travel funds or per diem from the city for attendance at meetings, seminars, training, or other educational events and fail to attend such events without promptly reimbursing the city therefor. (p) No city official shall attempt to unduly influence the outcome of a case before the municipal court of the city nor shall any city official engage in ex parte communication with a municipal court judge of the city on any matter pending before the municipal court of the city. (Ord. of 7-30-2011, § 1) Sec. 2-116. - Conflict of interest. (a) A city official may not participate in a vote or decision on a matter affecting an immediate family member or any person, entity, or property in which the official has a substantial interest. (b) A city official who serves as a corporate officer or member of the board of directors of a nonprofit entity must disclose their interest in said entity to the mayor and council prior to participating in a vote or decision regarding funding of the entity by or through the city. (c) Where the interest of a city official in the subject matter of a vote or decision is remote or incidental, the city official may participate in the vote or decision and need not disclose the interest. (Ord. of 7-30-2011, § 1) Sec. 2-117. - Board of ethics. The municipal court of the city shall hear and render decisions on all proper verified complaints filed under this division. (Ord. of 7-30-2011, § 1; Ord. of 4-2-2012, § 1) Sec. 2-118. - Receipt of complaints. (a) All complaints against city officials shall be filed with the clerk of the municipal court of the city. Upon receipt of a complaint in proper form, the municipal court clerk shall forward a copy of the complaint to the city official or officials charged in the complaint within no more than seven calendar days. (b) All complaints shall be submitted and signed under oath, shall be legibly drawn and shall clearly address matters within the scope of this division. (c) Upon receipt of a complaint in proper form, the municipal court shall review it to determine whether the complaint is unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded, or fails to state facts sufficient to invoke the disciplinary jurisdiction of the city council. The municipal court is empowered to dismiss in writing complaints that it determines are unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded, or fail to state facts sufficient to invoke the disciplinary jurisdiction of the city council; provided, however, that a rejection of such complaint by the municipal court shall not deprive the complaining party of any action such party might otherwise have at law or in equity against the city official. For complaints that are not dismissed, the municipal court is empowered to collect evidence and information concerning any complaint and add the findings and results of its investigations to the file containing such complaint. (d) Upon completion of its investigation of a complaint, the municipal court is empowered to dismiss in writing those complaints which it determines are unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded, or which fail to state facts sufficient to invoke the disciplinary jurisdiction of the city council; provided, however, that a rejection of such complaint by the municipal court shall not deprive the complaining party of any action such party might otherwise have at law or in equity against the city official. (e) The municipal court is empowered to conduct investigations, to take evidence, and to hold hearings to address the subject matter of a complaint. (f) The municipal court is empowered to adopt forms for formal complaints, notices, and any other necessary or desirable documents within its jurisdiction where the city council has not prescribed such forms. (g) Findings of the municipal court shall be submitted to the city council for action. (Ord. of 7-30-2011, § 1; Ord. of 4-2-2012, §§ 2,3) Sec. 2-119. - Service of complaint. The city clerk or municipal court as appointed herein set forth shall cause the complaint to be served on the city official charged as soon as practicable but in no event later than seven calendar days after receipt of a proper, verified complaint. Service may be by personal service, by certified mail, return receipt requested or by statutory overnight delivery. A hearing shall be held within 60 calendar days after filing of the complaint. The municipal court shall conduct hearings in accordance with the procedures and regulations it establishes but, in all circumstances, at least one hearing shall include the taking of testimony and the cross-examination of available witnesses. The decision of the municipal court shall be rendered to mayor and council within seven calendar days after completion of the final hearing. At any hearing held by the municipal court, the city official who is the subject of inquiry shall have the right to written notice of the hearing and the allegations at least seven calendar days before the first hearing, to be represented by counsel, to hear and examine the evidence and witnesses, and to oppose or try to mitigate the allegations. The city official subject to the inquiry shall also have the right but not the obligation of submitting evidence and calling witnesses. Failure to comply with any of the time deadlines in this section of the division shall not invalidate any otherwise valid complaint or in any way affect the power or jurisdiction of the municipal court or the city council to act upon any complaint. (Ord. of 7-30-2011, § 1; Ord. of 4-2-2012, § 3) Sec. 2-120. - Right to appeal. (a) Any city official or complainant adversely affected by the findings or recommendations of the municipal court may obtain judicial review of such decision as provided in this section. (b) An action for judicial review may be commenced by filing an application for a writ of certiorari in the Superior Court of Pickens County within 30 days after the decision of the municipal court. The filing of such application shall act as supersedeas. (Ord. of 7-30-2011, § 1; Ord. of 4-2-2012, § 3) Sec. 2-121. - Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this article is subject to: (1) Public reprimand or censure by the city council; or (2) Request for resignation by the city council. (Ord. of 7-30-2011, § 1) Secs. 2-122—2-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - FINANCE[6] Footnotes: --- (6) --- Cross reference— Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-6(2); taxation, ch. 46; financial institutions, § 46-141 et seq. State Law reference— Power of expenditure, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ II; grants of state funds to municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-40-1 et seq.; discretion of governing body as to management and disposition of property, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-2.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-131—2-150. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PURCHASING, SALE AND CONTRACTS[7]
Footnotes: --- (7) --- State Law reference— Multiyear lease, purchase or lease purchase contracts, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-13; purchases through state, O.C.G.A. § 50-5-100 et seq.
Sec. 2-151. - Purchasing generally. Operating under the oversight of the mayor and the supervision of the director of financial services, all purchases for the city shall be made in accordance with the provisions of the city financial management plan, any other requirements established by the mayor and city council, and any requirements contained in the laws of the state. If there is any conflict in such requirements, the laws of the state shall control. Sec. 2-152. - Contracts for public works. All contracts to build or repair any public building, bridge, causeway, road or other public work shall be let and contracted for in the manner prescribed by O.C.G.A. tit. 36, ch. 10. Sec. 2-153. - Bidding procedures. All purchases which are required to be made by competitive bid shall be made in accordance with formal competitive bidding procedures as set forth in the city financial management plan and the laws of the state. Upon any conflict in the procedures in the city financial management plan and the laws of the state, the procedures set out in the laws of the state shall control. Sec. 2-154. - Sale of surplus personal property. The director of financial services shall have the authority to sell personal property of the city which has become unsuitable for use; provided that surplus, unusable or obsolete supplies and equipment shall be sold only upon the adoption of a resolution by the mayor and city council specifying the manner in which such sale shall be conducted. Sec. 2-155. - Sale of small parcels of surplus real property. The city shall have the authority to sell and convey parcels of small or narrow strips of land, so shaped or so small as to be incapable of being used independently as zoned or under applicable subdivision or other development ordinances or land use plans, or as streets, whether owned in fee or used by easement, to abutting property owners upon the following terms and conditions: (1) Such sale and conveyance facilitates the enjoyment of the highest and best use of the purchaser's abutting property; (2) The property has been declared by the mayor and city council to be surplus real property; (3) Each owner of property which abuts the surplus property has been notified, at least 14 calendar days prior to such conveyance, by certified mail, return receipt requested, that the surplus property is being offered for sale and is given the opportunity to purchase such property under the terms and conditions set out in this section; (4) The sale has been authorized by resolution of the mayor and city council; (5) Title to the surplus real property shall be conveyed by quitclaim deed or limited warrant deed as the mayor and city council shall determine; (6) The purchase price shall be payable in cash at closing, which closing shall occur within 30 days of the approval of the sale by the mayor and city council; and (7) The purchaser shall be responsible for payment of all costs associated with the purchase of the surplus property, including, but not limited to, any attorney's fees, surveyor's fees and recording fees in connection therewith. Sec. 2-156. - City contracts. (a) Execution. Unless otherwise specified by a majority of the entire mayor and city council, the chairman or, in his absence the vice-chairman, shall execute all contracts to be entered into by the city. The clerk or, in his absence any deputy clerk, may attest the signature of the chairman or vice-chairman on any such contract. (b) Authorization. All contracts entered into by the mayor and city council shall be authorized as required by section 2-152.

div.head: Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority to adopt rules and regulations relating to manufacture, sale and distribution of distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-49; Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 6-1. - Public drinking or consumption of alcohol. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to consume alcoholic beverages while on or in a public way, or upon any way that is public, or upon any way that the public has the right of access to, to include private parking areas open to the general public. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to consume alcoholic beverages upon any city-owned property. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person to be or appear to be in an intoxicated condition upon any public place or within the curtilage of any private residence not his own, other than by invitation by the owner or lawful occupant, which conditions are made manifest by boisterous, or by indecent conditions or acts, or by vulgar, profane, loud or unbecoming language. (d) Alcoholic beverage possession is prohibited at school events. It shall be unlawful for any person to bring or carry into any enclosed field or auditorium where events sponsored or participated in by any public school are being held. (Ord. of 5-3-94, § 1) Sec. 6-2. - Possession of open container while operating a motor vehicle. (a) Definition. As used in this section, the term "open container" means any container which is immediately capable of being consumed from or the seal of which has been broken. (b) Possession. No person shall possess an open container of any alcoholic beverage while operating a motor vehicle in the city. For the purposes of this section, an open container shall be considered to be in the possession of the operator of a vehicle if the container is not in the possession of a passenger and is not located in a locked glove compartment, locked truck, or locked nonpassenger area of the vehicle. (Ord. of 5-3-94, § 2) Cross reference— Traffic, ch. 50. Secs. 6-3—6-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DISTILLED SPIRITS[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Authority to adopt rules and regulations relating to manufacture, sale and distribution of distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-49; levy of tax on sale of distilled spirits by the package authorized, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-80.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 6-31. - State law compliance. All pertinent state laws and regulations shall be complied with by any licensee under this article as a condition of having that license. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 8-3; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (f)) Sec. 6-32. - Hours and days of sale generally. Any person licensed under this article may sell distilled spirits according to the tenure of his license only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. on Monday through Saturday of each week, except that such sales shall not be permitted on Christmas Day. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 8-1; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (f)) Sec. 6-33. - Sale on election days. The sale or offer of sale of alcoholic beverages on election days by persons or businesses otherwise licensed by the city to sale alcoholic beverages shall be lawful. (Res. of 12-3-1985) Sec. 6-34. - Proximity of sale to churches. The sale of distilled spirits within 300 feet from the property line of any church, as measured by the most direct route of travel on the ground, is unlawful. (Res. of 5-1-1984) Sec. 6-35. - C.O.D. sales. All sales of distilled spirits authorized under this article must be completed at the location licensed. C.O.D. sales are specifically prohibited. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 8-2; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (f)) Sec. 6-36. - Minors. No sale of distilled spirits shall be conducted by minors or to minors. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 8-4; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (f)) Sec. 6-37. - Health and fire standards. Licensees under this article shall meet and continue to meet all health and fire regulations applicable to their business and location. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 8-6; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (f)) Sec. 6-38. - Purchase invoices. Each licensee under this article shall maintain copies of all purchase invoices for distilled spirits at his place of business and have such invoices available for examination by city officials at any time during normal working hours. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 8-7; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (f)) Sec. 6-39. - Inspection. It shall be the duty of the city police or other constituted authorities to inspect all establishments licensed pursuant to this article periodically to determine that no violations hereof exist. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 8-8; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (f)) Sec. 6-40. - Discounts. No licensee under this article shall allow bargain or reduced prices or discounts on the sale of distilled spirits. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 8-9; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (f)) Sec. 6-41. - No delivery. Licensees under this article or employees of such licensees shall not deliver any beer or wine beyond the premises of the establishment. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 8-10; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (f)) Sec. 6-42. - Automatic forfeiture. Any holder of any license issued under this article who shall for a period of three consecutive months after the license has been issued cease to operate the business and sale of the product or products authorized shall, after a three-month period, automatically forfeit his license without the necessity of any further action. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 8-11; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (f)) Secs. 6-43—6-60. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSE
Sec. 6-61. - Scope. Licenses issued under this division shall be for the sale of distilled spirits for consumption off the premises only. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 1-2; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (a)) Sec. 6-62. - State department of revenue approval required. Each license issued under this division is subject to the initial and ongoing approval and licensing of the state department of revenue. Failure to obtain or loss of such state approval shall operate as an automatic revocation of the licensee's city license to sell distilled spirits. Any beer and wine license shall not be affected thereby, so long as the licensee remains in compliance with this chapter. (Ord. of 4-3-1984, § III(a)) Sec. 6-63. - Applicant qualifications. (a) Age and competence. Any applicant for a license under this division, or agent for an applicant, shall be 25 years of age or older, an American citizen, and of sufficient mental competence to execute a contract under the laws of the state. (b) Criminal record. No applicant-in-interest shall have been convicted of, plead guilty to, or plead nolo contendere to any felony or misdemeanor charge, other than traffic offenses, within ten years of the date of submission of the application. Nor shall any such applicant have been incarcerated, on probation, or on parole within the five years preceding the date of submission of the application as a result of any felony conviction, plea of guilty, or plea of nolo contendere. The same exclusions shall apply as concerns the spouse of any applicant-in-interest. (c) Family involvement. No more than one license shall be issued to an applicant if any applicant-in-interest shall have a family member to the first degree of consanguinity or affinity as defined by state law which such member shall have an interest, direct or indirect, in any other license issued under this chapter, or in the ownership of or employment in any manufacturer or wholesaler of malt beverages or wines licensed to do business in the city. (d) Partnerships. An application made in the name of any partnership or limited partnership shall designate an individual from among the general partners to be the agent for contact and notice as regards the issuance and maintenance of any license authorized under this division. Such an application shall further list the names, business and home addresses of all general and limited partners associated with the application. Any change in a general partnership applicant or license holder shall require that a request for transfer of the license to the new partnership be submitted to the mayor and council. (e) Corporations. An application made in the name of any corporation duly authorized to do business in the state shall designate an individual as agent, who shall be responsible for the management of the location at which the license is requested and be the designated agent for contact and notice as regards the issuance and maintenance of any license authorized under this division. The names, business and home addresses shall be furnished with the application for the officers and directors of any corporate applicant and for any stockholder holding more than one percent in the aggregate of the common stock of the corporation. Such officers, directors and stockholders shall meet the criteria of subsections (a) and (b) of this section in order to acquire and maintain a license. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, §§ 3-1—3-6; Ord. of 9-6-1977; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (b)) Sec. 6-64. - Applications. (a) All applications for licenses under this division shall be under oath and shall, upon submission, contain all information called for by the several provisions of this division or specific negative averments as to their existence. The identity of the applicants shall include home and business addresses and telephone numbers, social security numbers and dates of birth to assist in the positive identification of individuals for verification purposes. The location for which a license is requested shall be described in as much detail as is necessary to identify such location for the purposes of verifying compliance with the provisions of this division, to include, if necessary, maps, legal descriptions, architectural renderings, etc. (b) All applications shall be submitted on forms provided therefor by the mayor and council or any party designated for the provision thereof. If no form has been approved, applications may be submitted in any form which clearly presents the information required by this division. (c) Applications shall be submitted in duplicate to the mayor and council and shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. Such fees shall cover the costs of investigation and verification of applications. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, §§ 2-1—2-3; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (a)) Sec. 6-65. - Approval of site. (a) Each site proposed for a license under this division shall, in order to be considered for approval, have a building which is a size of at least 1,500 square feet. (b) In addition, each site must have at least 1,600 square feet of paved parking area, such pavement to be properly maintained at all times by the licensee. (c) The building and premises shall comply fully in all respects with applicable federal, state and county standards, as well as with city fire, health, safety and other standards. (d) No site shall be approved where any portion of the building used by the licensee is nearer than 500 feet to any of the following: (1) Any church-owned property. (2) Any park operated by the city, county or state, or any school. (3) Residence proximity shall be considered on a case-by-case basis. (e) No site shall be approved which is not contiguous to State Highway Five. Specifically, the premises must have ingress and egress to such highway. (f) There shall be no drive-in windows for the sale of distilled spirits. (g) Licensees shall comply with applicable county regulations. If the parcel is situated in both counties, the septic tank regulations of the county with the most stringent standards shall be complied with. (Ord. of 4-3-1984, § I) Sec. 6-66. - Public notice of application. If, after receipt of the verification report on an application for a license under this division, the mayor finds the application to be prima facie satisfactory, he shall so notify the applicant. The applicant shall then place an advertisement in the legal notices section of the newspaper in which such notices are placed for the city. Such advertisement shall contain the name and address of the applicant, and its agent if any, and the location for which the license is sought. The advertisement shall run once a week for two consecutive weeks. The cost of advertisement shall be borne by the applicant. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 2-4; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (a)) Sec. 6-67. - Hearing or affidavit submission. Any citizen shall have the right to submit a sworn affidavit challenging the qualification of any prospective license under this division or prospective location at any time up to seven days after the last legal notice publication. The mayor and council may request further investigation or call a public hearing on proper notice if such affidavits are received. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 2-5; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (a)) Sec. 6-68. - Approval/disapproval. (a) After all procedures called for under this division have been completed, the mayor and council shall determine if all of the qualifications for the issuance of a license have been met. If it is determined that such is the case, then the mayor and council shall issue the license applied for, the same to be effective upon payment of the appropriate license fee until January 1 of the year following that in which the license becomes effective. (b) If the mayor and council determine at any time that the application fails to meet the qualifications of this division, they shall reject the application and notify the applicant of the rejection by certified mail stating the reasons for the rejection. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, §§ 2-7, 2-8; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (a)) Sec. 6-69. - Conditional approval. The mayor and council may approve or disapprove licenses notwithstanding compliance with all other provisions in this division, based upon the plans for building and business operation submitted by the proposed licensee if, in the judgement of a majority of the council (the mayor voting upon a question in this regard) and mayor such proposed establishment would constitute a nuisance or an unseemly establishment or a menace to the public health or welfare. If the building is not constructed as per the original plans submitted to the city by the proposed licensee, then the license shall be withheld, unless, in the judgement of the council and mayor, such deviation from initial plans constitute an improvement over the initial plans. (Ord. of 4-3-1984, § III(b)) Sec. 6-70. - Appeal from rejection of application. An applicant under this division who has been rejected by the mayor and council may file a request for hearing before the mayor and council if he contends that the application did meet the qualifications on which grounds it was rejected. The decision of the majority of the mayor and council as to the disputed requirements shall be binding as to further processing of the application. If any of the grounds for rejection is upheld by the entire mayor and council on appeal, the application shall stand rejected, and shall otherwise be returned to the mayor for the completion of processing and subsequent approval or disapproval on other grounds. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 2-9; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (a)) Sec. 6-71. - Reapplication. An unsuccessful applicant under this division may not submit a new application for the same location for 12 months after the date of the original submission. An unsuccessful applicant may submit a new application for a different location at any time after the final rejection of the prior application. No applicant may have more than one application for a license outstanding at the same time. Any reapplication shall be a new application in all respects. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 2-10; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (a)) Sec. 6-72. - License fees. The fee for a license issued under this division shall be as set forth in the schedule of rates and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. of 4-3-1984, § II(a)) Sec. 6-73. - Annual renewal. (a) A request for renewal of a license issued under this division shall be submitted by the holder thereof to the mayor and council not later than December 1 of each year. (b) Upon receipt of the application for renewal and audited revenue figures, the mayor and council shall issue a license renewal unless the current license shall at that time be suspended or revoked. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, §§ 5-1, 5-2; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (c)) Sec. 6-74. - Transfer. (a) Individuals. Licenses issued under this division in the name of an individual shall be transferable to any prospective new licensee who meets the criteria for the initial issuance of a license. A transfer request shall be submitted containing all the data required for an initial application, excluding that which applies solely to location. All public notice, verification and issuance procedures called for in this division shall be performed as to the prospective transferee. (b) Partnerships. Changes in a general partnership license shall be treated as a transfer request and shall proceed in the same manner as in subsection (a) of this section. (c) Corporations. Changes in the officers, directors and major stockholders shall not require a transfer of a license which is issued to the corporation. The names, business addresses, and home addresses of such new officers, directors or major stockholders shall be furnished to the mayor and council within 30 days of such changes. (d) Location changes. No transfer of license to a new location shall be permitted where such move is other than as a result of government action. Any change which is a result of government action shall authorize the transfer of a license to a new location provided that such location meets all the qualifying criteria for a location in an initial application. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, §§ 6-1—6-5; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (d)) Sec. 6-75. - Suspension and revocation. (a) Grounds. It shall constitute grounds for the suspension and revocation of any license issued under this division that the licensee no longer meets the qualifications required of an initial applicant, or has violated other restrictions or regulations applicable to a licensee and contained in this article. The violation of any state or federal law applicable to the possession or sale of beer, wine and distilled spirits shall also constitute grounds for suspension and revocation. (b) Procedures. Upon discovery of any violation authorizing a suspension or revocation of a license under this division, or upon the receipt of an affidavit from any citizen alleging such a violation, the mayor shall decide whether the license in question should be suspended pending the completion of investigation and the provision of a hearing for the licensee concerning the proposed revocation. Should the mayor elect to suspend the license for good cause shown, he may do so, and shall have notice of such suspension and the hearing date served upon the licensee or the agent in charge at the license location by the city police chief. (c) Appeal. A licensee whose license has been suspended may appeal to the mayor and council for a hearing if he wishes to further contest the accuracy of the findings upon which the suspension was grounded. The decision of the majority of the mayor and council as to the disputed grounds shall be binding in any further proceeding on the proposed revocation. If any of the grounds for suspension is upheld by the council on appeal, the license shall stand revoked; it shall otherwise be reinstated. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, §§ 7-1—7-5; Ord. of 4-3-1984, Preamble (e)) Secs. 6-76—6-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - BEER AND WINE[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Local license required for wholesale or retail sales of wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-40.

(Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 1-2) Sec. 6-132. - Applicant qualifications. (a) Age and competence. Nor shall any such applicant have been incarcerated, on probation, or on parole within the five years preceding the date of submission of the application as a result of any felony conviction, plea of guilty, or plea of nolo contendere. The same exclusions shall apply as concerns the spouse of any applicant-in-interest. (c) Family involvement. No more than one license shall be issued to an applicant if any applicant-in-interest shall have a family member to the first degree of consanguinity or affinity as defined by state law which such member shall have an interest, direct or indirect, in any other license issued under this division, or in the ownership of or employment in any manufacturer or wholesaler of beer or wine licensed to do business in the city. (d) Partnerships. An application made in the name of any partnership or limited partnership shall designate an individual from among the general partners to be the agent for contact and notice as regards the issuance and maintenance of any license authorized under this division. Such an application shall further list the names, business and home addresses of all general and limited partners associated with the application. Any change in a general partnership applicant or license holder shall require that a request for transfer of the license to the new partnership be submitted to the mayor and council. (e) Corporations. An application made in the name of any corporation duly authorized to do business in the state shall designate an individual as agent, who shall be responsible for the management of the location at which the license is requested and be the designated agent for contact and notice as regards the issuance and maintenance of any license authorized under this division. The names, business and home addresses shall be furnished with the application for the officers and directors of any corporate applicant and for any stockholder holding more than one percent in the aggregate of the common stock of the corporation. Such officers, directors and stockholders shall meet the criteria of subsections (a) and (b) of this section in order to acquire and maintain a license. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, §§ 3-1—3-6; Ord. of 9-6-1977) Sec. 6-133. - Applications. (a) All applications for licenses under this division shall be under oath and shall, upon submission, contain all information called for by the several provisions of this division or specific negative averments as to their existence. The identity of the applicants shall include home and business addresses and telephone numbers, social security numbers and dates of birth to assist in the positive identification of individuals for verification purposes. The location for which a license is requested shall be described in as much detail as is necessary to identify such location for the purposes of verifying compliance with the provisions of this division, to include, if necessary, maps, legal descriptions, architectural renderings, etc. (b) All applications shall be submitted on forms provided therefor by the mayor and council or any party designated for the provision thereof. If no form has been approved, applications may be submitted in any form which clearly presents the information required by this division. (c) Applications shall be submitted in duplicate to the mayor and council and shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. Such fees shall cover the costs of investigation and verification of applications. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, §§ 2-1—2-3) Sec. 6-134. - Public notice of application. If, after receipt of the verification report on an application for a license under this division, the mayor finds the application to be prima facie satisfactory, he shall so notify the applicant. The applicant shall then place an advertisement in the legal notices section of the newspaper in which such notices are placed for the city. Such advertisement shall contain the name and address of the applicant, and its agent if any, and the location for which the license is sought. The advertisement shall run once a week for two consecutive weeks. The cost of advertisement shall be borne by the applicant. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 2-4) Sec. 6-135. - Hearing or affidavit submission. Any citizen shall have the right to submit a sworn affidavit challenging the qualification of any prospective license under this division or prospective location at any time up to seven days after the last legal notice publication. The mayor and council may request further investigation or call a public hearing on proper notice if such affidavits are received. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 2-5) Sec. 6-136. - Approval/disapproval. (a) After all procedures called for under this division have been completed, the mayor and council shall determine if all of the qualifications for the issuance of a license have been met. If it is determined that such is the case, then the mayor and council shall issue the license applied for, the same to be effective upon payment of the appropriate license fee until January 1 of the year following that in which the license becomes effective. (b) If the mayor and council determine at any time that the application fails to meet the qualifications of this division, they shall reject the application and notify the applicant of the rejection by certified mail stating the reasons for the rejection. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, §§ 2-7, 2-8) Sec. 6-137. - Appeal from rejection of application. An applicant under this division who has been rejected by the mayor and council may file a request for hearing before the mayor and council if he contends that the application did meet the qualifications on which grounds it was rejected. The decision of the majority of the mayor and council as to the disputed requirements shall be binding as to further processing of the application. If any of the grounds for rejection is upheld by the entire mayor and council on appeal, the application shall stand rejected. It shall otherwise be returned to the mayor for the completion of processing and subsequent approval or disapproval on other grounds. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 2-9) Sec. 6-138. - Reapplication. An unsuccessful applicant under this division may not submit a new application for the same location for 12 months after the date of the original submission. An unsuccessful applicant may submit a new application for a different location at any time after the final rejection of the prior application. No applicant may have more than one application for a license outstanding at the same time. Any reapplication shall be a new application in all respects. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 2-10) Sec. 6-139. - Prior operation of business. Any location for which a license is applied for under this division must be an operating entity at that location for at least three months prior to the filing of the license application. It is not required that the applicant has been the owner or lessor of such premises for such time period. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 4-1) Sec. 6-140. - Building standards. The physical premises for which a license is sought under this division shall comply in all respects with the city building codes and all applicable fire, health and other safety standards. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 4-2) Sec. 6-141. - Proximity standards. No location specified in an application for a license under this division shall be within 500 feet of a public library, church, public park or schoolground. All measurements shall be from the center of the front door of the applicant's establishment to the nearest property line of the restricted entities. If an establishment has two or more customer entrance doors, such measurement shall be made, and such restrictions apply from each such door. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 4-3) Sec. 6-142. - Annual renewal. (a) A request for renewal of a license issued under this division shall be submitted by the holder thereof to the mayor and council not later than December 1 of each year. (b) Upon receipt of the application for renewal and audited revenue figures, the mayor and council shall issue a license renewal unless the current license shall at that time be suspended or revoked. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, §§ 5-1, 5-2) Sec. 6-143. - Transfer. (a) Individuals. Licenses issued under this division in the name of an individual shall be transferable to any prospective new licensee who meets the criteria for the initial issuance of a license. A transfer request shall be submitted containing all the data required for an initial application, excluding that which applies solely to location. All public notice, verification and issuance procedures called for in this division shall be performed as to the prospective transferee. (b) Partnerships. Changes in a general partnership license shall be treated as a transfer request and shall proceed in the same manner as in subsection (a) of this section. (c) Corporations. Changes in the officers, directors and major stockholders shall not require a transfer of a license which is issued to the corporation. The names, business addresses, and home addresses of such new officers, directors or major stockholders shall be furnished to the mayor and council within 30 days of such changes. (d) Location changes. No transfer of license to a new location shall be permitted where such move is other than as a result of government action. Any change which is a result of government action shall authorize the transfer of a license to a new location provided that such location meets all the qualifying criteria for a location in an initial application. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, §§ 6-1—6-5) Sec. 6-144. - Suspension and revocation. (a) Grounds. It shall constitute grounds for the suspension and revocation of any license issued under this division that the licensee no longer meets the qualifications required of an initial applicant, or has violated other restrictions or regulations applicable to a licensee and contained in this article. The violation of any state or federal law applicable to the possession or sale of beer and wine shall also constitute grounds for suspension and revocation. (b) Procedures. Upon discovery of any violation authorizing a suspension or revocation of a license under this division, or upon the receipt of an affidavit from any citizen alleging such a violation, the mayor shall decide whether the license in question should be suspended pending the completion of investigation and the provision of a hearing for the licensee concerning the proposed revocation. Should the mayor elect to suspend the license for good cause shown, he may do so, and shall have notice of such suspension and the hearing date served upon the licensee or the agent in charge at the license location by the city police chief. (c) Appeal. A licensee whose license has been suspended may appeal to the mayor and council for a hearing if he wishes to further contest the accuracy of the findings upon which the suspension was grounded. The decision of the majority of the mayor and council as to the disputed grounds shall be binding in any further proceeding on the proposed revocation. If any of the grounds for suspension is upheld by the council on appeal, the license shall stand revoked; it shall otherwise be reinstated. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, §§ 7-1—7-5) Secs. 6-145—6-170. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - EXCISE TAXES[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- State Law reference— Imposition of excise tax on malt beverages required, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80.
Sec. 6-171. - Penalty for violation of article. Any person who shall submit a return required by this article which is false or fraudulent, or who shall assist any person to evade the payment of any license tax provided in this article, shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11. Sec. 6-172. - Beer excise tax; imposition; collection. (a) There is imposed and levied a specific tax upon all retail beer dealers within the city limits as follows: (1) Where beer, commonly known as tap or draft beer, is sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, a tax of $6.00 on each container sold containing not more than 15½ gallons and a proportional tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 15½ gallons. (2) Where beer is sold in bottles, cans or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of $0.05 per 12 ounces and a proportional tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 12 ounces. (b) Each distributor, wholesale dealer or manufacturer selling, shipping or delivering beer to any retail dealer in the city shall collect the excise tax as set forth in subsection (a) of this section and shall remit the tax to the city not later than the tenth of the month following collection. Each monthly remittance will be accompanied by invoice copies of all sales or deliveries to all retailers in the city for resale in the city, together with the sworn affidavit of such distributor, wholesale dealer or manufacturer, that the attached invoices are true, correct and complete. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, §§ 9-1, 9-4, 9-5) State Law reference— Imposition of excise tax on malt beverages required, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80. Sec. 6-173. - Wine excise tax; imposition; collection. (a) In addition to the annual retail wine license fee, there is levied an excise tax computed at the rate of $0.22 per liter, and a proportional tax on all fractional parts of a liter which shall be paid to the city on all wine sold, displayed or stored in the incorporated area of the city. The tax shall be collected by wholesale distributors and paid to the city by the wholesale distributors on all wine sold to retailers in the incorporated area of the city as follows: Each wholesale distributor selling, shipping, or in any way delivering wine to any retailer shall collect the excise tax at the time of delivery and shall remit the tax, together with a summary of all deliveries to each retailer, on or before the tenth day of the following month. (b) It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any retailer to possess, own, hold, store, display or sell any wine on which the tax has not been paid. (c) Each wholesale distributor shall furnish to the mayor and council a summary of all purchase invoices for wine sold to each retailer in the incorporated area of the city on or before the 15th day of each month following such purchases. The invoices shall show the amount of excise tax paid. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, §§ 9-1, 9-6) State Law reference— Authorization to levy tax on wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-60. Sec. 6-174. - Distilled spirits excise tax. (a) In addition to the annual retail liquor license fee, there is levied an excise tax computed at the rate of three percent of the charge to the public for the beverages. (b) No tax authorized by subsection (a) of this section may be imposed, levied and collected in any portion of the county in which a similar tax is levied and collected by any municipality. (c) The tax imposed by this section shall not apply to the sale of fermented beverages made in whole or in part from malt or any similar fermented beverage. (Ord. of 4-3-1984, § II(b)) State Law reference— Authority to impose excise tax on sale of distilled spirits by the drink, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-130. Sec. 6-175. - Retailers' records. All retail dealers in beer, wine and/or distilled spirits, and all persons selling beer, wine and/or distilled spirits at retail, shall keep a complete and correct record of all purchases of beer, wine and distilled spirits, and shall require all persons from whom they purchase beer, wine and distilled spirits to furnish and deliver to them, at the time of delivery of such beverages, a correct invoice of purchase, which invoice shall be kept and preserved by the retailer at his place of business for a period of six months from the date of purchase. Such invoices and all records of retailers of beer, wine and/or distilled spirits shall be subject to inspection by any authorized representative of the city. All records of purchase shall be kept a period of at least three years from the date of such purchase or sale before being destroyed. (Ord. of 8-6-1977, § 9-3)

div.head: Chapter 10 - ANIMALS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 26; noise from animals and birds, § 26-38; disposal of dead animals, § 42-10. State Law reference— Authority to exercise animal control, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(3); Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 10-1. - Enforcement. Any person found to be in violation of this chapter shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-11. Any fine, when collected, shall be paid to the city and shall become part of the city general fund. In addition to fines levied, any individual found to be in violation of this chapter will be required to reimburse the city general fund for any costs incurred by the city during abatement procedures. (Ord. of 12-5-2000, § 5) Sec. 10-2. - Unattended animals at large. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any animal or any person having an animal to allow it to run at large unattended. (Ord. of 12-5-2000, § 1) Sec. 10-3. - Animals at large. (a) On streets, highways. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any animal or any person having an animal in his custody, to allow it to run at large unattended on or about the streets and highways of the city. (b) On private property. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any animal or any person having an animal in his custody, to allow it to run at large unattended on the property of another person without permission of the owner of that property or of the person in possession of that property. (Ord. of 12-5-2000, § 2) Sec. 10-4. - Control of animals. (a) Generally. It shall be the duty of every owner of any animal, or any person having any animal in his possession or custody, to ensure that the animal is enclosed by a fence or other enclosure or is restrained by a chain or leash or in some other physical manner or under control by a competent person so that it cannot wander off of the real property limits of its owner, possessor or custodian except as provided in this article. (b) Off premises of owner. It shall be the duty of the owner of any animal, or any person having an animal in his possession, to keep that animal under control at all times while the animal is off the real property limits of the owner, possessor, or custodian. (Ord. of 12-5-2000, § 2) Sec. 10-5. - Fowl at large. It shall be unlawful for any person to allow fowl of any kind to run at large in the city. (Ord. of 12-5-2000, § 2) Sec. 10-6. - Abandonment of animals. It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly abandon any animal within the city. Each person who knowingly abandons an animal or willingly permits such abandonment, or aids in the abandonment of any animal, shall be in violation of this section. (Ord. of 12-5-2000, § 2) Sec. 10-7. - Permit for wild, exotic, dangerous or nondomestic animals. No person shall have, keep or maintain any wild, exotic, dangerous or nondomestic animal or reptile without first applying to and receiving from the police department a permit to do so. The charge for this permit shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. of 12-5-2000, § 2) Sec. 10-8. - Identification of owners. It shall be the duty of every owner of any animal, or any person having any animal in his possession or custody, to ensure that the animal wears a collar with a tag identifying the name, address and telephone number of the owner. (Ord. of 12-5-2000, § 2) Sec. 10-9. - Swine prohibited. No hogs shall be kept within the city. (Ord. of 12-5-2000, § 2) Sec. 10-10. - Agricultural animals. No new agricultural animals such as cattle, sheep, goats, horses, gamebirds, etc., may be raised or kept within the city limits after December 5, 2000. Residents raising or keeping the aforementioned animals, on December 5, 2000, may continue to maintain their current animals but may not expand with new animals, or replace animals as they are sold, removed, die or are otherwise disposed of. However, should the keeping of animals in accordance with this section present a nuisance to the public, or to the immediate neighbors of the person owning or keeping such animals, then that issue will be addressed on a case by case basis by the municipal court. (Ord. of 12-5-2000, § 2) Secs. 10-11—10-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ABATEMENT PROCEDURES
Sec. 10-41. - Initiation. Proceedings to abate a violation of this chapter, whether public or private, shall be initiated by the filing of a complaint with the city police department. Such complaint shall state the nature and location of the violation and the name and address of the complainant or complainants. In the case of a private violation, the complaint shall be filed by the person injured by the violation. In the case of a public violation, the complaint will be filed on behalf of the public by a city official. (Ord. of 12-5-2000, § 4(1)) Sec. 10-42. - Notice of hearing. If, upon investigation of a complaint under this article, the city police department finds evidence to support the complaint, a citation shall be issued, with such citation being bound over to municipal court. (Ord. of 12-5-2000, § 4(2)) Sec. 10-43. - Removal of animal. If the owner of an animal running at large is known, the owner will be directed by the police to retrieve and properly control the animal. At the discretion of the police officer, the owner may be issued a citation to appear in municipal court for violation of this chapter. If the owner of an animal running at large cannot be determined, the city may arrange for the removal of the animal by the county animal control or by a private contractor. (Ord. of 12-5-2000, § 4(3)) ARTICLE III. - ADOPTION OF CHEROKEE COUNTY ANIMAL CONTROL ORDINANCE
Sec. 10-44. - Adoption. The city hereby adopts the Cherokee County Animal Control Ordinance, as codified in chapter 10 of the Cherokee County Code of Ordinances, in its entirety, with the exceptions that the phrase "Cherokee County" shall be replaced by the phrase "the City of Nelson" and that the phrase "the county" shall be replaced by the phrase "the city," unless such references relate to the agreement for Cherokee County to provide animal control services to the City of Nelson. (Ord. of 8-4-2008) Sec. 10-45. - Fees. The incorporated areas of the City of Nelson shall be subject to the fees charged by the Cherokee County Marshal's Office and all of said fees shall be retained by Cherokee County to defray the costs of the marshal's office related to animal control. (Ord. of 8-4-2008) Sec. 10-46. - Conflicting provisions. If any provision of the Animal Control Ordinance herein adopted conflicts with any other provision of the Code of the City of Nelson, the provisions of this article III shall control. (Ord. of 8-4-2008) Secs. 10-47—10-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - ADOPTION OF PICKENS COUNTY ANIMAL CONTROL ORDINANCE
Sec. 10-61. - Adoption. The city hereby adopts, for enforcement within the incorporated areas of the City of Nelson which are located within the boundaries of Pickens County, the Pickens County Animal Control Ordinance, as codified in chapter 14 of the Pickens County Code of Ordinances, in its entirety, with the exceptions that the phrase "Pickens County" shall be replaced by the phrase "the City of Nelson" and that the phrase "the county" shall be replaced by the phrase "the city," unless such references relate to the agreement for Pickens County to provide animal control services to the City of Nelson. (Ord. of 2-7-2011) Sec. 10-62. - Fees. The incorporated areas of the City of Nelson shall be subject to the fees charged by the Pickens County Sheriff and all of said fees shall be retained by Pickens County to defray the costs of the sheriff related to animal control. (Ord. of 2-7-2011) Sec. 10-63. - Conflicting provisions. If any provision of the Animal Control Ordinance herein adopted conflicts with any other provision of the Code of the City of Nelson, the provisions of this article IV shall control. (Ord. of 2-7-2011)

div.head: Chapter 14 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 26; construction or repairing of buildings, § 26-43; flood control, ch. 30; manufactured housing, ch. 34; solid waste, ch. 42. State Law reference— Construction standards generally, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 14-1. - Self-inspection by plumbers, utility contractors. The city is exempted from the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26(d) relating to the self-inspection of certain water and sewer lines, and such provisions shall not be applicable in the city. Secs. 14-2—14-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION CODES
Sec. 14-31. - Adopted. (a) Enumeration. The following codes, the latest edition as adopted and amended by the state department of community affairs, shall be enforced by the city: (1) Standard Building Code; (2) Standard Mechanical Code; (3) Standard Gas Code; (4) Standard Plumbing Code; (5) National Electrical Code; (6) Standard Fire Prevention Code; (7) CABO One and Two Family Dwelling Code; and (8) Georgia State Energy Code for Buildings. (b) Appendices. The following appendices of the codes adopted in subsection (a) of this section are adopted by reference as though they were copied fully in this subsection: (1) Standard Building Code: Appendix; (2) Standard Mechanical Code: Appendix; (3) Standard Gas Code: Appendix; (4) Standard Plumbing Code: Appendix; (5) Standard Fire Prevention Code: Appendix; (6) National Electrical Code: Appendix; and (7) CABO One and Two Family Dwelling Code: Appendix. (c) Additional codes. The latest edition of the following codes, as adopted and amended by the state department of community affairs, are adopted by reference as though they were fully copied in this subsection: (1) Standard Housing Code, including Chapter 1, Administration and Appendix; (2) Standard Swimming Pool Code, including Chapter 1, Administration; (3) Standard Excavation and Grading Code, including Chapter 1, Administration; (4) Standard Unsafe Building Abatement Code, including Chapter 1, Administration; (5) Standard Existing Building Code, including Chapter 1, Administration and Appendix; and (6) Standard Amusement Device Code, including Chapter 1, Administration and Appendix. State Law reference— Authority to adopt technical codes, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(12); construction standards generally, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.; minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25. Sec. 14-32. - Compliance. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the construction or erection of any building, whether commercial, business or residential, unless such construction is accomplished in strict compliance with the various construction codes adopted by this article. Sec. 14-33. - Enforcement. When reference is made to the duties of certain officials named in the various construction codes adopted by this article, the designated city official shall be deemed to be the responsible official for the enforcement of such codes. Sec. 14-34. - Penalty for violation. (a) Any person violating any provision of the various construction codes adopted by this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. (b) A conviction of any provision of the various construction codes adopted by this article shall automatically suspend the business license of the offending contractor. The license may be reinstated by an application to the mayor and council upon a showing of good cause. Sec. 14-35. - Permit required. Each owner of land desiring to improve, build or construct new construction or additions to improved property shall make application for and obtain a building permit from the city. (Ord. of 8-8-1996, § 1) Sec. 14-36. - Permit and inspection fees. Permit and inspection fees and any other charges imposed or due under the various construction codes adopted by this article shall be as provided in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. of 8-8-1996, § 2) Sec. 14-37. - Public utilities. (a) No public utility may furnish temporary electrical, water or gas connection for construction purposes, unless the contractor has been issued a construction permit by the chief building official. (b) No public utility may furnish permanent electrical, water or gas connections until the contractor has been issued a certificate of occupancy by the chief building official. (c) No public utility may furnish power to a mobile home site until the owner has been issued either a building permit or a certificate of occupancy by the chief building official. Sec. 14-38. - Water supply and sewage disposal facilities. (a) Building permits will not be issued until plans for water supply and sewage disposal have been approved by the county board of health. (b) Certificates of occupancy will not be issued until the completed water supply and sewage disposal facilities have been approved by the county board of health. State Law reference— Regulations for septic tanks in unincorporated areas; conformity prerequisite to building permit, O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.l. Secs. 14-39—14-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - FLOW-RATE RESTRICTIONS ON PLUMBING FIXTURES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Flow-rate restrictions on plumbing fixtures, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-3.
Sec. 14-71. - Purpose of article. It is the purpose of this article to: (1) Require the use of ultra-low-flow plumbing fixtures in all new construction or when replacing plumbing fixtures during renovation or remodeling of existing buildings; (2) Require the certification of plumbing fixtures regarding flow rates and serviceability standards; (3) Promote compliance with state laws for the purpose of conserving water; (4) Maintain the integrity of drinking water supplies; and (5) Reduce wastewater flows. Sec. 14-72. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial building means any type of building other than residential. Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building, and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet, or urinal in an existing building. Plumbing fixture means any toilet, urinal, showerhead, bathroom, lavatory and kitchen faucet and replacement aerator. Residential building means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling but shall not include a hotel or motel. Toilet means any fixture consisting of a water-flushed bowl with a seat, used for the disposal of human waste. Urinal means any fixture consisting of a water-flushed bowl used for the disposal of human waste. Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 14-73. - Enforcement; penalty for violation of article. Citations for violations of this article may be issued by the building official or his authorized representative. Any person violating this article shall be tried before the municipal court. Upon conviction, such person found guilty of a violation of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. Sec. 14-74. - Standards for fixtures. No plumbing fixture shall be installed which does not meet the standards listed in this section or the state plumbing code, whichever is stricter. This includes all plumbing fixtures installed in newly constructed buildings or when replacing plumbing fixtures during remodeling or renovation of existing buildings, except as noted in section 14-76. The effective date of this requirement for residential buildings shall be April 1, 1992, and for commercial buildings the effective date shall be July 1, 1992. (1) All plumbing fixtures installed as referred to in this section shall not exceed the following maximum water use rates: a. Toilets, 1.6 gallons per flush. b. Urinals, 1.0 gallon per flush. c. Showerheads, 2.5 gallons per minute, at 60 psi gauge pressure. d. Kitchen faucets, 2.5 gallons per minute. e. Bathroom and lavatory faucets, 2.0 gallons per minute. (2) The flow restriction device in a showerhead must be a permanent and integral part of the showerhead and must not be removable to allow flow rates in excess of that stated in subsection (1) of this section. (3) Lavatory faucets located in restrooms intended for use by the general public shall be of the metering or self-closing type, in addition to the flow requirement listed in subsection (1) of this section. (4) The flow rates for all showerheads and kitchen, bathroom and lavatory faucets shall be determined in accordance with ANSI/ASME A112.18.1M—1989 Plumbing Fixture Fittings, as amended; except that maximum flow rates may not exceed those given in subsection (1) of this section. (5) All toilets and urinals shall be certified to meet the hydraulic performance standards for low consumption water closets specified in ANSI/ASME A112.19.2—1990 Vitreous China Plumbing Fixtures, as amended, and ANSI/ASME A112.19.6—1990 Hydraulic Requirements for Water Closets and Urinals, as amended. Sec. 14-75. - Product certification. The manufacturer shall certify compliance with the standards in section 14-74 by labeling the fixture and packaging as described in this section and providing, upon request, appropriate certification by an independent national testing organization acceptable to the city building official. Effective April 1, 1992, all toilets, urinals, showerheads or faucets shall be clearly labeled to indicate the maximum flow rate or water usage of the fixture at the specified test pressure. Toilets and urinals shall additionally be labeled ASME A112.19.2M, as prescribed in section 8 of such standard. The label shall be affixed to the fixture and remain there until the proper building and/or plumbing inspections have been conducted. Also, the packaging must be clearly marked to identify water use rates when offered for retail. Sec. 14-76. - Exceptions. Permission for the exceptions listed in this section must be obtained from the building official. New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building may be exempt from the standards of section 14-74 for the following: (1) Showers and faucets installed for safety purposes, such as emergency eye wash stations, etc. (2) Plumbing fixtures specifically designed for the physically handicapped. (3) Fixtures specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or for installation in a correctional institution which may require more water for proper operation. (4) Instances of building renovation where significant plumbing modifications would be required to accommodate the lower flows or for specialized purposes that cannot be accommodated by existing technology.

Sec. 22-1. - Adoption of state rules, regulations. The rules and regulations promulgated by the state election board that pertain to municipal elections, together with the provisions of the state municipal election code contained in O.C.G.A. § 21-3-1 et seq., are adopted as the rules, regulations and provisions that shall govern the conduct of municipal, general and special elections in the city. (Ord. of 8-1-95) Sec. 22-3. - Voting machines. The use of vote records and tabulating machines for recording and computing the vote at elections held within the city is authorized in city elections, except when the use of voting machines is impracticable. (Ord. of 9-9-93) Sec. 22-4. - Expenses. Such funds as are necessary for the conduct of elections and for the performance of the duties that are specified by this chapter shall be budgeted and appropriated annually, and at other times when required. Sec. 22-5. - Polling places, voting precincts. The polling places and voting precincts of the city shall be as shown on the official map on file in the office of the city clerk.
